instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00850: What is 820-00850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck on 5V 0,01A
threads.message:
on all 4 ports the same
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.26V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is missing

short to GND in  <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
via thermal camera and injection of 2V found damaged <CAPACITOR>C7807</CAPACITOR>
i pulled it from the board, the short is also away, in diode mode i get L7660 Pin 1  0.413 was 0,0

board back in the case with accu, no difference, 

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is now 0.6V

checked <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> all pins in diode mode almost like in the boardview (openboarddata)

checked all pins of all 4 ports, all ok



need some help what now ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck on 5V 0,01A
threads.message:
foud burned <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR>

like in repairwiki described "... If <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> had a short circuit, but the board stays at 5V and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is still missing, it can be due to <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> (0 Ohm Resistor between <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> and <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> PMIC, that takes <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> input and outputs it as <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>). Short cuircuit on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> can burn out <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> (may be visually intact). Check <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> resistance. ..."

working now 
problem solved
